evidence: task-specific measures such as sensitivity and specificity, ROC and AUC analysis, human and mathematical observers, and even modern approaches like neural networks and radiomics
These measures shift our attention from the imaging device itself to the diagnostic performance of the entire workflow

When manufacturers design an imaging system, they often advertise its specifications - resolution, noise levels, dose reduction, acquisition speed, and so on. These system specs are useful, but in practice, they don't directly answer the most important question: Can the system help us make the right clinical decision?
triples.o: whether the imaging system can successfully support the clinical task
